summary.long: 1 Kings is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: King David was now very old, and no matter how many blankets covered him, he could not keep warm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So his advisers told him, “Let us find a young virgin to wait on you and look after you, my lord. She will lie in your arms and keep you warm.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they searched throughout the land of Israel for a beautiful girl, and they found Abishag from Shunem and brought her to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The girl was very beautiful, and she looked after the king and took care of him. But the king had no sexual relations with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About that time David’s son Adonijah, whose mother was Haggith, began boasting, “I will make myself king.” So he provided himself with chariots and charioteers and recruited fifty men to run in front of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now his father, King David, had never disciplined him at any time, even by asking, “Why are you doing that?” Adonijah had been born next after Absalom, and he was very handsome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah took Joab son of Zeruiah and Abiathar the priest into his confidence, and they agreed to help him become king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Zadok the priest, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and David’s personal bodyguard refused to support Adonijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah went to the Stone of Zoheleth near the spring of En-rogel, where he sacrificed sheep, cattle, and fattened calves. He invited all his brothers—the other sons of King David—and all the royal officials of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he did not invite Nathan the prophet or Benaiah or the king’s bodyguard or his brother Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nathan went to Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother, and asked her, “Haven’t you heard that Haggith’s son, Adonijah, has made himself king, and our lord David doesn’t even know about it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you want to save your own life and the life of your son Solomon, follow my advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go at once to King David and say to him, ‘My lord the king, didn’t you make a vow and say to me, “Your son Solomon will surely be the next king and will sit on my throne”? Why then has Adonijah become king?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And while you are still talking with him, I will come and confirm everything you have said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Bathsheba went into the king’s bedroom. (He was very old now, and Abishag was taking care of him.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bathsheba bowed down before the king.
“What can I do for you?” he asked her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She replied, “My lord, you made a vow before the Lord your God when you said to me, ‘Your son Solomon will surely be the next king and will sit on my throne.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But instead, Adonijah has made himself king, and my lord the king does not even know about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has sacrificed many cattle, fattened calves, and sheep, and he has invited all the king’s sons to attend the celebration. He also invited Abiathar the priest and Joab, the commander of the army. But he did not invite your servant Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, my lord the king, all Israel is waiting for you to announce who will become king after you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you do not act, my son Solomon and I will be treated as criminals as soon as my lord the king has died.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While she was still speaking with the king, Nathan the prophet arrived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king’s officials told him, “Nathan the prophet is here to see you.”
Nathan went in and bowed before the king with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan asked, “My lord the king, have you decided that Adonijah will be the next king and that he will sit on your throne?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today he has sacrificed many cattle, fattened calves, and sheep, and he has invited all the king’s sons to attend the celebration. He also invited the commanders of the army and Abiathar the priest. They are feasting and drinking with him and shouting, ‘Long live King Adonijah!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he did not invite me or Zadok the priest or Benaiah or your servant Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Has my lord the king really done this without letting any of his officials know who should be the next king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David responded, “Call Bathsheba!” So she came back in and stood before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the king repeated his vow: “As surely as the Lord lives, who has rescued me from every danger,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: your son Solomon will be the next king and will sit on my throne this very day, just as I vowed to you before the Lord, the God of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Bathsheba bowed down with her face to the ground before the king and exclaimed, “May my lord King David live forever!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David ordered, “Call Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada.” When they came into the king’s presence,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the king said to them, “Take Solomon and my officials down to Gihon Spring. Solomon is to ride on my own mule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet are to anoint him king over Israel. Blow the ram’s horn and shout, ‘Long live King Solomon!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then escort him back here, and he will sit on my throne. He will succeed me as king, for I have appointed him to be ruler over Israel and Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Amen!” Benaiah son of Jehoiada replied. “May the Lord, the God of my lord the king, decree that it happen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And may the Lord be with Solomon as he has been with you, my lord the king, and may he make Solomon’s reign even greater than yours!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and the king’s bodyguard took Solomon down to Gihon Spring, with Solomon riding on King David’s own mule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There Zadok the priest took the flask of olive oil from the sacred tent and anointed Solomon with the oil. Then they sounded the ram’s horn and all the people shouted, “Long live King Solomon!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the people followed Solomon into Jerusalem, playing flutes and shouting for joy. The celebration was so joyous and noisy that the earth shook with the sound.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah and his guests heard the celebrating and shouting just as they were finishing their banquet. When Joab heard the sound of the ram’s horn, he asked, “What’s going on? Why is the city in such an uproar?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And while he was still speaking, Jonathan son of Abiathar the priest arrived. “Come in,” Adonijah said to him, “for you are a good man. You must have good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Not at all!” Jonathan replied. “Our lord King David has just declared Solomon king!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king sent him down to Gihon Spring with Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada, protected by the king’s bodyguard. They had him ride on the king’s own mule,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Zadok and Nathan have anointed him at Gihon Spring as the new king. They have just returned, and the whole city is celebrating and rejoicing. That’s what all the noise is about.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What’s more, Solomon is now sitting on the royal throne as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the royal officials have gone to King David and congratulated him, saying, ‘May your God make Solomon’s fame even greater than your own, and may Solomon’s reign be even greater than yours!’ Then the king bowed his head in worship as he lay in his bed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he said, ‘Praise the Lord, the God of Israel, who today has chosen a successor to sit on my throne while I am still alive to see it.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all of Adonijah’s guests jumped up in panic from the banquet table and quickly scattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah was afraid of Solomon, so he rushed to the sacred tent and grabbed on to the horns of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Word soon reached Solomon that Adonijah had seized the horns of the altar in fear, and that he was pleading, “Let King Solomon swear today that he will not kill me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon replied, “If he proves himself to be loyal, not a hair on his head will be touched. But if he makes trouble, he will die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Solomon summoned Adonijah, and they brought him down from the altar. He came and bowed respectfully before King Solomon, who dismissed him, saying, “Go on home.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the time of King David’s death approached, he gave this charge to his son Solomon:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am going where everyone on earth must someday go. Take courage and be a man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Observe the requirements of the Lord your God, and follow all his ways. Keep the decrees, commands, regulations, and laws written in the Law of Moses so that you will be successful in all you do and wherever you go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you do this, then the Lord will keep the promise he made to me. He told me, ‘If your descendants live as they should and follow me faithfully with all their heart and soul, one of them will always sit on the throne of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And there is something else. You know what Joab son of Zeruiah did to me when he murdered my two army commanders, Abner son of Ner and Amasa son of Jether. He pretended that it was an act of war, but it was done in a time of peace, staining his belt and sandals with innocent blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do with him what you think best, but don’t let him grow old and go to his grave in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Be kind to the sons of Barzillai of Gilead. Make them permanent guests at your table, for they took care of me when I fled from your brother Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And remember Shimei son of Gera, the man from Bahurim in Benjamin. He cursed me with a terrible curse as I was fleeing to Mahanaim. When he came down to meet me at the Jordan River, I swore by the Lord that I would not kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But that oath does not make him innocent. You are a wise man, and you will know how to arrange a bloody death for him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David died and was buried with his ancestors in the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had reigned over Israel for forty years, seven of them in Hebron and thirty-three in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon became king and sat on the throne of David his father, and his kingdom was firmly established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One day Adonijah, whose mother was Haggith, came to see Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother. “Have you come with peaceful intentions?” she asked him.
“Yes,” he said, “I come in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In fact, I have a favor to ask of you.”
“What is it?” she asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied, “As you know, the kingdom was rightfully mine; all Israel wanted me to be the next king. But the tables were turned, and the kingdom went to my brother instead; for that is the way the Lord wanted it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So now I have just one favor to ask of you. Please don’t turn me down.”
“What is it?” she asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied, “Speak to King Solomon on my behalf, for I know he will do anything you request. Ask him to let me marry Abishag, the girl from Shunem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All right,” Bathsheba replied. “I will speak to the king for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Bathsheba went to King Solomon to speak on Adonijah’s behalf. The king rose from his throne to meet her, and he bowed down before her. When he sat down on his throne again, the king ordered that a throne be brought for his mother, and she sat at his right hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I have one small request to make of you,” she said. “I hope you won’t turn me down.”
“What is it, my mother?” he asked. “You know I won’t refuse you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then let your brother Adonijah marry Abishag, the girl from Shunem,” she replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How can you possibly ask me to give Abishag to Adonijah?” King Solomon demanded. “You might as well ask me to give him the kingdom! You know that he is my older brother, and that he has Abiathar the priest and Joab son of Zeruiah on his side.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Solomon made a vow before the Lord: “May God strike me and even kill me if Adonijah has not sealed his fate with this request.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has confirmed me and placed me on the throne of my father, David; he has established my dynasty as he promised. So as surely as the Lord lives, Adonijah will die this very day!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Solomon ordered Benaiah son of Jehoiada to execute him, and Adonijah was put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Abiathar the priest, “Go back to your home in Anathoth. You deserve to die, but I will not kill you now, because you carried the Ark of the Sovereign Lord for David my father and you shared all his hardships.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon deposed Abiathar from his position as priest of the Lord, thereby fulfilling the prophecy the Lord had given at Shiloh concerning the descendants of Eli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab had not joined Absalom’s earlier rebellion, but he had joined Adonijah’s rebellion. So when Joab heard about Adonijah’s death, he ran to the sacred tent of the Lord and grabbed on to the horns of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When this was reported to King Solomon, he sent Benaiah son of Jehoiada to execute him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benaiah went to the sacred tent of the Lord and said to Joab, “The king orders you to come out!”
But Joab answered, “No, I will die here.”
So Benaiah returned to the king and told him what Joab had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do as he said,” the king replied. “Kill him there beside the altar and bury him. This will remove the guilt of Joab’s senseless murders from me and from my father’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will repay him for the murders of two men who were more righteous and better than he. For my father knew nothing about the deaths of Abner son of Ner, commander of the army of Israel, and of Amasa son of Jether, commander of the army of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May their blood be on Joab and his descendants forever, and may the Lord grant peace forever to David, his descendants, his dynasty, and his throne.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Benaiah son of Jehoiada returned to the sacred tent and killed Joab, and he was buried at his home in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king appointed Benaiah to command the army in place of Joab, and he installed Zadok the priest to take the place of Abiathar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king then sent for Shimei and told him, “Build a house here in Jerusalem and live there. But don’t step outside the city to go anywhere else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day you so much as cross the Kidron Valley, you will surely die; and your blood will be on your own head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei replied, “Your sentence is fair; I will do whatever my lord the king commands.” So Shimei lived in Jerusalem for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But three years later two of Shimei’s slaves ran away to King Achish son of Maacah of Gath. When Shimei learned where they were,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he saddled his donkey and went to Gath to search for them. When he found them, he brought them back to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon heard that Shimei had left Jerusalem and had gone to Gath and returned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king sent for Shimei and demanded, “Didn’t I make you swear by the Lord and warn you not to go anywhere else or you would surely die? And you replied, ‘The sentence is fair; I will do as you say.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then why haven’t you kept your oath to the Lord and obeyed my command?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also said to Shimei, “You certainly remember all the wicked things you did to my father, David. May the Lord now bring that evil on your own head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But may I, King Solomon, receive the Lord’s blessings, and may one of David’s descendants always sit on this throne in the presence of the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then, at the king’s command, Benaiah son of Jehoiada took Shimei outside and killed him.
So the kingdom was now firmly in Solomon’s grip.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made an alliance with Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, and married one of his daughters. He brought her to live in the City of David until he could finish building his palace and the Temple of the Lord and the wall around the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time the people of Israel sacrificed their offerings at local places of worship, for a temple honoring the name of the Lord had not yet been built.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon loved the Lord and followed all the decrees of his father, David, except that Solomon, too, offered sacrifices and burned incense at the local places of worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The most important of these places of worship was at Gibeon, so the king went there and sacrificed 1,000 burnt offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night the Lord appeared to Solomon in a dream, and God said, “What do you want? Ask, and I will give it to you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon replied, “You showed great and faithful love to your servant my father, David, because he was honest and true and faithful to you. And you have continued to show this great and faithful love to him today by giving him a son to sit on his throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, O Lord my God, you have made me king instead of my father, David, but I am like a little child who doesn’t know his way around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And here I am in the midst of your own chosen people, a nation so great and numerous they cannot be counted!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give me an understanding heart so that I can govern your people well and know the difference between right and wrong. For who by himself is able to govern this great people of yours?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was pleased that Solomon had asked for wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God replied, “Because you have asked for wisdom in governing my people with justice and have not asked for a long life or wealth or the death of your enemies—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give you what you asked for! I will give you a wise and understanding heart such as no one else has had or ever will have!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will also give you what you did not ask for—riches and fame! No other king in all the world will be compared to you for the rest of your life!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if you follow me and obey my decrees and my commands as your father, David, did, I will give you a long life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon woke up and realized it had been a dream. He returned to Jerusalem and stood before the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant, where he sacrificed burnt offerings and peace offerings. Then he invited all his officials to a great banquet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later two prostitutes came to the king to have an argument settled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Please, my lord,” one of them began, “this woman and I live in the same house. I gave birth to a baby while she was with me in the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later this woman also had a baby. We were alone; there were only two of us in the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But her baby died during the night when she rolled over on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she got up in the night and took my son from beside me while I was asleep. She laid her dead child in my arms and took mine to sleep beside her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And in the morning when I tried to nurse my son, he was dead! But when I looked more closely in the morning light, I saw that it wasn’t my son at all.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the other woman interrupted, “It certainly was your son, and the living child is mine.”
“No,” the first woman said, “the living child is mine, and the dead one is yours.” And so they argued back and forth before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said, “Let’s get the facts straight. Both of you claim the living child is yours, and each says that the dead one belongs to the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All right, bring me a sword.” So a sword was brought to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said, “Cut the living child in two, and give half to one woman and half to the other!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the woman who was the real mother of the living child, and who loved him very much, cried out, “Oh no, my lord! Give her the child—please do not kill him!”
But the other woman said, “All right, he will be neither yours nor mine; divide him between us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said, “Do not kill the child, but give him to the woman who wants him to live, for she is his mother!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all Israel heard the king’s decision, the people were in awe of the king, for they saw the wisdom God had given him for rendering justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon now ruled over all Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and these were his high officials:
Azariah son of Zadok was the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Elihoreph and Ahijah, the sons of Shisha, were court secretaries.
Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the royal historian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benaiah son of Jehoiada was commander of the army.
Zadok and Abiathar were priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Azariah son of Nathan was in charge of the district governors.
Zabud son of Nathan, a priest, was a trusted adviser to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahishar was manager of the palace property.
Adoniram son of Abda was in charge of forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also had twelve district governors who were over all Israel. They were responsible for providing food for the king’s household. Each of them arranged provisions for one month of the year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the names of the twelve governors:
Ben-hur, in the hill country of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben-deker, in Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth-shemesh, and Elon-bethhanan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben-hesed, in Arubboth, including Socoh and all the land of Hepher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben-abinadab, in all of Naphoth-dor. (He was married to Taphath, one of Solomon’s daughters.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baana son of Ahilud, in Taanach and Megiddo, all of Beth-shan near Zarethan below Jezreel, and all the territory from Beth-shan to Abel-meholah and over to Jokmeam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben-geber, in Ramoth-gilead, including the Towns of Jair (named for Jair of the tribe of Manasseh) in Gilead, and in the Argob region of Bashan, including sixty large fortified towns with bronze bars on their gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahinadab son of Iddo, in Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahimaaz, in Naphtali. (He was married to Basemath, another of Solomon’s daughters.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baana son of Hushai, in Asher and in Aloth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat son of Paruah, in Issachar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei son of Ela, in Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Geber son of Uri, in the land of Gilead, including the territories of King Sihon of the Amorites and King Og of Bashan.
There was also one governor over the land of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Judah and Israel were as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They were very contented, with plenty to eat and drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon ruled over all the kingdoms from the Euphrates River in the north to the land of the Philistines and the border of Egypt in the south. The conquered peoples of those lands sent tribute money to Solomon and continued to serve him throughout his lifetime.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The daily food requirements for Solomon’s palace were 150 bushels of choice flour and 300 bushels of meal;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: also 10 oxen from the fattening pens, 20 pasture-fed cattle, 100 sheep or goats, as well as deer, gazelles, roe deer, and choice poultry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s dominion extended over all the kingdoms west of the Euphrates River, from Tiphsah to Gaza. And there was peace on all his borders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the lifetime of Solomon, all of Judah and Israel lived in peace and safety. And from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south, each family had its own home and garden.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had 4,000 stalls for his chariot horses, and he had 12,000 horses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The district governors faithfully provided food for King Solomon and his court; each made sure nothing was lacking during the month assigned to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also brought the necessary barley and straw for the royal horses in the stables.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God gave Solomon very great wisdom and understanding, and knowledge as vast as the sands of the seashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In fact, his wisdom exceeded that of all the wise men of the East and the wise men of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was wiser than anyone else, including Ethan the Ezrahite and the sons of Mahol—Heman, Calcol, and Darda. His fame spread throughout all the surrounding nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He composed some 3,000 proverbs and wrote 1,005 songs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He could speak with authority about all kinds of plants, from the great cedar of Lebanon to the tiny hyssop that grows from cracks in a wall. He could also speak about animals, birds, small creatures, and fish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And kings from every nation sent their ambassadors to listen to the wisdom of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hiram of Tyre had always been a loyal friend of David. When Hiram learned that David’s son Solomon was the new king of Israel, he sent ambassadors to congratulate him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon sent this message back to Hiram:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You know that my father, David, was not able to build a Temple to honor the name of the Lord his God because of the many wars waged against him by surrounding nations. He could not build until the Lord gave him victory over all his enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now the Lord my God has given me peace on every side; I have no enemies, and all is well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I am planning to build a Temple to honor the name of the Lord my God, just as he had instructed my father, David. For the Lord told him, ‘Your son, whom I will place on your throne, will build the Temple to honor my name.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, please command that cedars from Lebanon be cut for me. Let my men work alongside yours, and I will pay your men whatever wages you ask. As you know, there is no one among us who can cut timber like you Sidonians!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hiram received Solomon’s message, he was very pleased and said, “Praise the Lord today for giving David a wise son to be king of the great nation of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he sent this reply to Solomon:
“I have received your message, and I will supply all the cedar and cypress timber you need.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My servants will bring the logs from the Lebanon mountains to the Mediterranean Sea and make them into rafts and float them along the coast to whatever place you choose. Then we will break the rafts apart so you can carry the logs away. You can pay me by supplying me with food for my household.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hiram supplied as much cedar and cypress timber as Solomon desired.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In return, Solomon sent him an annual payment of 100,000 bushels of wheat for his household and 110,000 gallons of pure olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord gave wisdom to Solomon, just as he had promised. And Hiram and Solomon made a formal alliance of peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Solomon conscripted a labor force of 30,000 men from all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent them to Lebanon in shifts, 10,000 every month, so that each man would be one month in Lebanon and two months at home. Adoniram was in charge of this labor force.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also had 70,000 common laborers, 80,000 quarry workers in the hill country,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and 3,600 foremen to supervise the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the king’s command, they quarried large blocks of high-quality stone and shaped them to make the foundation of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Men from the city of Gebal helped Solomon’s and Hiram’s builders prepare the timber and stone for the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was in midspring, in the month of Ziv, during the fourth year of Solomon’s reign, that he began to construct the Temple of the Lord. This was 480 years after the people of Israel were rescued from their slavery in the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Temple that King Solomon built for the Lord was 90 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 45 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entry room at the front of the Temple was 30 feet wide, running across the entire width of the Temple. It projected outward 15 feet from the front of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also made narrow recessed windows throughout the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built a complex of rooms against the outer walls of the Temple, all the way around the sides and rear of the building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The complex was three stories high, the bottom floor being 7 1⁄2 feet wide, the second floor 9 feet wide, and the top floor 10 1⁄2 feet wide. The rooms were connected to the walls of the Temple by beams resting on ledges built out from the wall. So the beams were not inserted into the walls themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The stones used in the construction of the Temple were finished at the quarry, so there was no sound of hammer, ax, or any other iron tool at the building site.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entrance to the bottom floor was on the south side of the Temple. There were winding stairs going up to the second floor, and another flight of stairs between the second and third floors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After completing the Temple structure, Solomon put in a ceiling made of cedar beams and planks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As already stated, he built a complex of rooms along the sides of the building, attached to the Temple walls by cedar timbers. Each story of the complex was 7 1⁄2 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord gave this message to Solomon:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Concerning this Temple you are building, if you keep all my decrees and regulations and obey all my commands, I will fulfill through you the promise I made to your father, David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will live among the Israelites and will never abandon my people Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon finished building the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire inside, from floor to ceiling, was paneled with wood. He paneled the walls and ceilings with cedar, and he used planks of cypress for the floors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He partitioned off an inner sanctuary—the Most Holy Place—at the far end of the Temple. It was 30 feet deep and was paneled with cedar from floor to ceiling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The main room of the Temple, outside the Most Holy Place, was 60 feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cedar paneling completely covered the stone walls throughout the Temple, and the paneling was decorated with carvings of gourds and open flowers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He prepared the inner sanctuary at the far end of the Temple, where the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant would be placed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This inner sanctuary was 30 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 30 feet high. He overlaid the inside with solid gold. He also overlaid the altar made of cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon overlaid the rest of the Temple’s interior with solid gold, and he made gold chains to protect the entrance to the Most Holy Place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he finished overlaying the entire Temple with gold, including the altar that belonged to the Most Holy Place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made two cherubim of wild olive wood, each 15 feet tall, and placed them in the inner sanctuary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wingspan of each of the cherubim was 15 feet, each wing being 7 1⁄2 feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two cherubim were identical in shape and size;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: each was 15 feet tall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He placed them side by side in the inner sanctuary of the Temple. Their outspread wings reached from wall to wall, while their inner wings touched at the center of the room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He overlaid the two cherubim with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He decorated all the walls of the inner sanctuary and the main room with carvings of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He overlaid the floor in both rooms with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the entrance to the inner sanctuary, he made double doors of wild olive wood with five-sided doorposts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These double doors were decorated with carvings of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers. The doors, including the decorations of cherubim and palm trees, were overlaid with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he made four-sided doorposts of wild olive wood for the entrance to the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were two folding doors of cypress wood, and each door was hinged to fold back upon itself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These doors were decorated with carvings of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers—all overlaid evenly with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The walls of the inner courtyard were built so that there was one layer of cedar beams between every three layers of finished stone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The foundation of the Lord’s Temple was laid in midspring, in the month of Ziv, during the fourth year of Solomon’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire building was completed in every detail by midautumn, in the month of Bul, during the eleventh year of his reign. So it took seven years to build the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also built a palace for himself, and it took him thirteen years to complete the construction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of Solomon’s buildings was called the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon. It was 150 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 45 feet high. There were four rows of cedar pillars, and great cedar beams rested on the pillars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The hall had a cedar roof. Above the beams on the pillars were forty-five side rooms, arranged in three tiers of fifteen each.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On each end of the long hall were three rows of windows facing each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the doorways and doorposts had rectangular frames and were arranged in sets of three, facing each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also built the Hall of Pillars, which was 75 feet long and 45 feet wide. There was a porch in front, along with a canopy supported by pillars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also built the throne room, known as the Hall of Justice, where he sat to hear legal matters. It was paneled with cedar from floor to ceiling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s living quarters surrounded a courtyard behind this hall, and they were constructed the same way. He also built similar living quarters for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had married.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From foundation to eaves, all these buildings were built from huge blocks of high-quality stone, cut with saws and trimmed to exact measure on all sides.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the huge foundation stones were 15 feet long, and some were 12 feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The blocks of high-quality stone used in the walls were also cut to measure, and cedar beams were also used.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The walls of the great courtyard were built so that there was one layer of cedar beams between every three layers of finished stone, just like the walls of the inner courtyard of the Lord’s Temple with its entry room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon then asked for a man named Huram to come from Tyre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was half Israelite, since his mother was a widow from the tribe of Naphtali, and his father had been a craftsman in bronze from Tyre. Huram was extremely skillful and talented in any work in bronze, and he came to do all the metal work for King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram cast two bronze pillars, each 27 feet tall and 18 feet in circumference.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the tops of the pillars he cast bronze capitals, each 7 1⁄2 feet tall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each capital was decorated with seven sets of latticework and interwoven chains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also encircled the latticework with two rows of pomegranates to decorate the capitals over the pillars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The capitals on the columns inside the entry room were shaped like water lilies, and they were six feet tall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The capitals on the two pillars had 200 pomegranates in two rows around them, beside the rounded surface next to the latticework.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram set the pillars at the entrance of the Temple, one toward the south and one toward the north. He named the one on the south Jakin, and the one on the north Boaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The capitals on the pillars were shaped like water lilies. And so the work on the pillars was finished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Huram cast a great round basin, 15 feet across from rim to rim, called the Sea. It was 7 1⁄2 feet deep and about 45 feet in circumference.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was encircled just below its rim by two rows of decorative gourds. There were about six gourds per foot all the way around, and they were cast as part of the basin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Sea was placed on a base of twelve bronze oxen, all facing outward. Three faced north, three faced west, three faced south, and three faced east, and the Sea rested on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The walls of the Sea were about three inches thick, and its rim flared out like a cup and resembled a water lily blossom. It could hold about 11,000 gallons of water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram also made ten bronze water carts, each 6 feet long, 6 feet wide, and 4 1⁄2 feet tall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were constructed with side panels braced with crossbars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Both the panels and the crossbars were decorated with carved lions, oxen, and cherubim. Above and below the lions and oxen were wreath decorations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each of these carts had four bronze wheels and bronze axles. There were supporting posts for the bronze basins at the corners of the carts; these supports were decorated on each side with carvings of wreaths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The top of each cart had a rounded frame for the basin. It projected 1 1⁄2 feet above the cart’s top like a round pedestal, and its opening was 2 1⁄4 feet across; it was decorated on the outside with carvings of wreaths. The panels of the carts were square, not round.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under the panels were four wheels that were connected to axles that had been cast as one unit with the cart. The wheels were 2 1⁄4 feet in diameter
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and were similar to chariot wheels. The axles, spokes, rims, and hubs were all cast from molten bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were handles at each of the four corners of the carts, and these, too, were cast as one unit with the cart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Around the top of each cart was a rim nine inches wide. The corner supports and side panels were cast as one unit with the cart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Carvings of cherubim, lions, and palm trees decorated the panels and corner supports wherever there was room, and there were wreaths all around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All ten water carts were the same size and were made alike, for each was cast from the same mold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram also made ten smaller bronze basins, one for each cart. Each basin was six feet across and could hold 220 gallons of water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set five water carts on the south side of the Temple and five on the north side. The great bronze basin called the Sea was placed near the southeast corner of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He also made the necessary washbasins, shovels, and bowls.
So at last Huram completed everything King Solomon had assigned him to make for the Temple of the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: the 400 pomegranates that hung from the chains on the capitals (two rows of pomegranates for each of the chain networks that decorated the capitals on top of the pillars);
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the ten water carts holding the ten basins;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Sea and the twelve oxen under it;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the ash buckets, the shovels, and the bowls.
Huram made all these things of burnished bronze for the Temple of the Lord, just as King Solomon had directed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king had them cast in clay molds in the Jordan Valley between Succoth and Zarethan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon did not weigh all these things because there were so many; the weight of the bronze could not be measured.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
the lampstands of solid gold, five on the south and five on the north, in front of the Most Holy Place;
the flower decorations, lamps, and tongs—all of gold;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the small bowls, lamp snuffers, bowls, ladles, and incense burners—all of solid gold;
the doors for the entrances to the Most Holy Place and the main room of the Temple, with their fronts overlaid with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Solomon finished all his work on the Temple of the Lord. Then he brought all the gifts his father, David, had dedicated—the silver, the gold, and the various articles—and he stored them in the treasuries of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon then summoned to Jerusalem the elders of Israel and all the heads of the tribes—the leaders of the ancestral families of the Israelites. They were to bring the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant to the Temple from its location in the City of David, also known as Zion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the men of Israel assembled before King Solomon at the annual Festival of Shelters, which is held in early autumn in the month of Ethanim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the elders of Israel arrived, the priests picked up the Ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests and Levites brought up the Ark of the Lord along with the special tent and all the sacred items that had been in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There, before the Ark, King Solomon and the entire community of Israel sacrificed so many sheep, goats, and cattle that no one could keep count!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the priests carried the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant into the inner sanctuary of the Temple—the Most Holy Place—and placed it beneath the wings of the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cherubim spread their wings over the Ark, forming a canopy over the Ark and its carrying poles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These poles were so long that their ends could be seen from the Holy Place, which is in front of the Most Holy Place, but not from the outside. They are still there to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nothing was in the Ark except the two stone tablets that Moses had placed in it at Mount Sinai, where the Lord made a covenant with the people of Israel when they left the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the priests came out of the Holy Place, a thick cloud filled the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests could not continue their service because of the cloud, for the glorious presence of the Lord filled the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon prayed, “O Lord, you have said that you would live in a thick cloud of darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I have built a glorious Temple for you, a place where you can live forever!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king turned around to the entire community of Israel standing before him and gave this blessing:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Praise the Lord, the God of Israel, who has kept the promise he made to my father, David. For he told my father,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘From the day I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I have never chosen a city among any of the tribes of Israel as the place where a Temple should be built to honor my name. But I have chosen David to be king over my people Israel.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon said, “My father, David, wanted to build this Temple to honor the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord told him, ‘You wanted to build the Temple to honor my name. Your intention is good,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but you are not the one to do it. One of your own sons will build the Temple to honor me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now the Lord has fulfilled the promise he made, for I have become king in my father’s place, and now I sit on the throne of Israel, just as the Lord promised. I have built this Temple to honor the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I have prepared a place there for the Ark, which contains the covenant that the Lord made with our ancestors when he brought them out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord in front of the entire community of Israel. He lifted his hands toward heaven,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and he prayed,
“O Lord, God of Israel, there is no God like you in all of heaven above or on the earth below. You keep your covenant and show unfailing love to all who walk before you in wholehearted devotion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have kept your promise to your servant David, my father. You made that promise with your own mouth, and with your own hands you have fulfilled it today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now, O Lord, God of Israel, carry out the additional promise you made to your servant David, my father. For you said to him, ‘If your descendants guard their behavior and faithfully follow me as you have done, one of them will always sit on the throne of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, O God of Israel, fulfill this promise to your servant David, my father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But will God really live on earth? Why, even the highest heavens cannot contain you. How much less this Temple I have built!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, listen to my prayer and my plea, O Lord my God. Hear the cry and the prayer that your servant is making to you today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May you watch over this Temple night and day, this place where you have said, ‘My name will be there.’ May you always hear the prayers I make toward this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May you hear the humble and earnest requests from me and your people Israel when we pray toward this place. Yes, hear us from heaven where you live, and when you hear, forgive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If someone wrongs another person and is required to take an oath of innocence in front of your altar in this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven and judge between your servants—the accuser and the accused. Punish the guilty as they deserve. Acquit the innocent because of their innocence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If your people Israel are defeated by their enemies because they have sinned against you, and if they turn to you and acknowledge your name and pray to you here in this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven and forgive the sin of your people Israel and return them to this land you gave their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If the skies are shut up and there is no rain because your people have sinned against you, and if they pray toward this Temple and acknowledge your name and turn from their sins because you have punished them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven and forgive the sins of your servants, your people Israel. Teach them to follow the right path, and send rain on your land that you have given to your people as their special possession.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If there is a famine in the land or a plague or crop disease or attacks of locusts or caterpillars, or if your people’s enemies are in the land besieging their towns—whatever disaster or disease there is—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and if your people Israel pray about their troubles, raising their hands toward this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven where you live, and forgive. Give your people what their actions deserve, for you alone know each human heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they will fear you as long as they live in the land you gave to our ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In the future, foreigners who do not belong to your people Israel will hear of you. They will come from distant lands because of your name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for they will hear of your great name and your strong hand and your powerful arm. And when they pray toward this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven where you live, and grant what they ask of you. In this way, all the people of the earth will come to know and fear you, just as your own people Israel do. They, too, will know that this Temple I have built honors your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If your people go out where you send them to fight their enemies, and if they pray to the Lord by turning toward this city you have chosen and toward this Temple I have built to honor your name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear their prayers from heaven and uphold their cause.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If they sin against you—and who has never sinned?—you might become angry with them and let their enemies conquer them and take them captive to their land far away or near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But in that land of exile, they might turn to you in repentance and pray, ‘We have sinned, done evil, and acted wickedly.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they turn to you with their whole heart and soul in the land of their enemies and pray toward the land you gave to their ancestors—toward this city you have chosen, and toward this Temple I have built to honor your name—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear their prayers and their petition from heaven where you live, and uphold their cause.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Forgive your people who have sinned against you. Forgive all the offenses they have committed against you. Make their captors merciful to them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for they are your people—your special possession—whom you brought out of the iron-smelting furnace of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “May your eyes be open to my requests and to the requests of your people Israel. May you hear and answer them whenever they cry out to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For when you brought our ancestors out of Egypt, O Sovereign Lord, you told your servant Moses that you had set Israel apart from all the nations of the earth to be your own special possession.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon finished making these prayers and petitions to the Lord, he stood up in front of the altar of the Lord, where he had been kneeling with his hands raised toward heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stood and in a loud voice blessed the entire congregation of Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Praise the Lord who has given rest to his people Israel, just as he promised. Not one word has failed of all the wonderful promises he gave through his servant Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord our God be with us as he was with our ancestors; may he never leave us or abandon us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May he give us the desire to do his will in everything and to obey all the commands, decrees, and regulations that he gave our ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And may these words that I have prayed in the presence of the Lord be before him constantly, day and night, so that the Lord our God may give justice to me and to his people Israel, according to each day’s needs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then people all over the earth will know that the Lord alone is God and there is no other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And may you be completely faithful to the Lord our God. May you always obey his decrees and commands, just as you are doing today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king and all Israel with him offered sacrifices to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon offered to the Lord a peace offering of 22,000 cattle and 120,000 sheep and goats. And so the king and all the people of Israel dedicated the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same day the king consecrated the central area of the courtyard in front of the Lord’s Temple. He offered burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat of peace offerings there, because the bronze altar in the Lord’s presence was too small to hold all the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat of the peace offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon and all Israel celebrated the Festival of Shelters in the presence of the Lord our God. A large congregation had gathered from as far away as Lebo-hamath in the north and the Brook of Egypt in the south. The celebration went on for fourteen days in all—seven days for the dedication of the altar and seven days for the Festival of Shelters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the festival was over, Solomon sent the people home. They blessed the king and went to their homes joyful and glad because the Lord had been good to his servant David and to his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon finished building the Temple of the Lord, as well as the royal palace. He completed everything he had planned to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord appeared to Solomon a second time, as he had done before at Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to him,
“I have heard your prayer and your petition. I have set this Temple apart to be holy—this place you have built where my name will be honored forever. I will always watch over it, for it is dear to my heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for you, if you will follow me with integrity and godliness, as David your father did, obeying all my commands, decrees, and regulations,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will establish the throne of your dynasty over Israel forever. For I made this promise to your father, David: ‘One of your descendants will always sit on the throne of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But if you or your descendants abandon me and disobey the commands and decrees I have given you, and if you serve and worship other gods,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will uproot Israel from this land that I have given them. I will reject this Temple that I have made holy to honor my name. I will make Israel an object of mockery and ridicule among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And though this Temple is impressive now, all who pass by will be appalled and will gasp in horror. They will ask, ‘Why did the Lord do such terrible things to this land and to this Temple?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And the answer will be, ‘Because his people abandoned the Lord their God, who brought their ancestors out of Egypt, and they worshiped other gods instead and bowed down to them. That is why the Lord has brought all these disasters on them.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It took Solomon twenty years to build the Lord’s Temple and his own royal palace. At the end of that time,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he gave twenty towns in the land of Galilee to King Hiram of Tyre. (Hiram had previously provided all the cedar and cypress timber and gold that Solomon had requested.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Hiram came from Tyre to see the towns Solomon had given him, he was not at all pleased with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What kind of towns are these, my brother?” he asked. So Hiram called that area Cabul (which means “worthless”), as it is still known today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, Hiram paid Solomon 9,000 pounds of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account of the forced labor that King Solomon conscripted to build the Lord’s Temple, the royal palace, the supporting terraces, the wall of Jerusalem, and the cities of Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, had attacked and captured Gezer, killing the Canaanite population and burning it down. He gave the city to his daughter as a wedding gift when she married Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon rebuilt the city of Gezer.) He also built up the towns of Lower Beth-horon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baalath, and Tamar in the wilderness within his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built towns as supply centers and constructed towns where his chariots and horses could be stationed. He built everything he desired in Jerusalem and Lebanon and throughout his entire realm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were still some people living in the land who were not Israelites, including Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were descendants of the nations whom the people of Israel had not completely destroyed. So Solomon conscripted them as slaves, and they serve as forced laborers to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Solomon did not conscript any of the Israelites for forced labor. Instead, he assigned them to serve as fighting men, government officials, officers and captains in his army, commanders of his chariots, and charioteers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon appointed 550 of them to supervise the people working on his various projects.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon moved his wife, Pharaoh’s daughter, from the City of David to the new palace he had built for her. Then he constructed the supporting terraces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three times each year Solomon presented burnt offerings and peace offerings on the altar he had built for the Lord. He also burned incense to the Lord. And so he finished the work of building the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon also built a fleet of ships at Ezion-geber, a port near Elath in the land of Edom, along the shore of the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram sent experienced crews of sailors to sail the ships with Solomon’s men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sailed to Ophir and brought back to Solomon some sixteen tons of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba heard of Solomon’s fame, which brought honor to the name of the Lord, she came to test him with hard questions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She arrived in Jerusalem with a large group of attendants and a great caravan of camels loaded with spices, large quantities of gold, and precious jewels. When she met with Solomon, she talked with him about everything she had on her mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had answers for all her questions; nothing was too hard for the king to explain to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba realized how very wise Solomon was, and when she saw the palace he had built,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: she was overwhelmed. She was also amazed at the food on his tables, the organization of his officials and their splendid clothing, the cup-bearers, and the burnt offerings Solomon made at the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She exclaimed to the king, “Everything I heard in my country about your achievements and wisdom is true!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I didn’t believe what was said until I arrived here and saw it with my own eyes. In fact, I had not heard the half of it! Your wisdom and prosperity are far beyond what I was told.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How happy your people must be! What a privilege for your officials to stand here day after day, listening to your wisdom!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Praise the Lord your God, who delights in you and has placed you on the throne of Israel. Because of the Lord’s eternal love for Israel, he has made you king so you can rule with justice and righteousness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she gave the king a gift of 9,000 pounds of gold, great quantities of spices, and precious jewels. Never again were so many spices brought in as those the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (In addition, Hiram’s ships brought gold from Ophir, and they also brought rich cargoes of red sandalwood and precious jewels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king used the sandalwood to make railings for the Temple of the Lord and the royal palace, and to construct lyres and harps for the musicians. Never before or since has there been such a supply of sandalwood.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba whatever she asked for, besides all the customary gifts he had so generously given. Then she and all her attendants returned to their own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each year Solomon received about 25 tons of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This did not include the additional revenue he received from merchants and traders, all the kings of Arabia, and the governors of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon made 200 large shields of hammered gold, each weighing more than fifteen pounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made 300 smaller shields of hammered gold, each weighing nearly four pounds. The king placed these shields in the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king made a huge throne, decorated with ivory and overlaid with fine gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The throne had six steps and a rounded back. There were armrests on both sides of the seat, and the figure of a lion stood on each side of the throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were also twelve other lions, one standing on each end of the six steps. No other throne in all the world could be compared with it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of King Solomon’s drinking cups were solid gold, as were all the utensils in the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon. They were not made of silver, for silver was considered worthless in Solomon’s day!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king had a fleet of trading ships of Tarshish that sailed with Hiram’s fleet. Once every three years the ships returned, loaded with gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Solomon became richer and wiser than any other king on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People from every nation came to consult him and to hear the wisdom God had given him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Year after year everyone who visited brought him gifts of silver and gold, clothing, weapons, spices, horses, and mules.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon built up a huge force of chariots and horses. He had 1,400 chariots and 12,000 horses. He stationed some of them in the chariot cities and some near him in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver as plentiful in Jerusalem as stone. And valuable cedar timber was as common as the sycamore-fig trees that grow in the foothills of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and from Cilicia; the king’s traders acquired them from Cilicia at the standard price.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time chariots from Egypt could be purchased for 600 pieces of silver, and horses for 150 pieces of silver. They were then exported to the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now King Solomon loved many foreign women. Besides Pharaoh’s daughter, he married women from Moab, Ammon, Edom, Sidon, and from among the Hittites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord had clearly instructed the people of Israel, “You must not marry them, because they will turn your hearts to their gods.” Yet Solomon insisted on loving them anyway.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had 700 wives of royal birth and 300 concubines. And in fact, they did turn his heart away from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Solomon’s old age, they turned his heart to worship other gods instead of being completely faithful to the Lord his God, as his father, David, had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon worshiped Ashtoreth, the goddess of the Sidonians, and Molech, the detestable god of the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way, Solomon did what was evil in the Lord’s sight; he refused to follow the Lord completely, as his father, David, had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the Mount of Olives, east of Jerusalem, he even built a pagan shrine for Chemosh, the detestable god of Moab, and another for Molech, the detestable god of the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon built such shrines for all his foreign wives to use for burning incense and sacrificing to their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was very angry with Solomon, for his heart had turned away from the Lord, the God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had warned Solomon specifically about worshiping other gods, but Solomon did not listen to the Lord’s command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now the Lord said to him, “Since you have not kept my covenant and have disobeyed my decrees, I will surely tear the kingdom away from you and give it to one of your servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But for the sake of your father, David, I will not do this while you are still alive. I will take the kingdom away from your son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And even so, I will not take away the entire kingdom; I will let him be king of one tribe, for the sake of my servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem, my chosen city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord raised up Hadad the Edomite, a member of Edom’s royal family, to be Solomon’s adversary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Years before, David had defeated Edom. Joab, his army commander, had stayed to bury some of the Israelite soldiers who had died in battle. While there, they killed every male in Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab and the army of Israel had stayed there for six months, killing them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hadad and a few of his father’s royal officials escaped and headed for Egypt. (Hadad was just a boy at the time.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set out from Midian and went to Paran, where others joined them. Then they traveled to Egypt and went to Pharaoh, who gave them a home, food, and some land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh grew very fond of Hadad, and he gave him his wife’s sister in marriage—the sister of Queen Tahpenes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She bore him a son named Genubath. Tahpenes raised him in Pharaoh’s palace among Pharaoh’s own sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the news reached Hadad in Egypt that David and his commander Joab were both dead, he said to Pharaoh, “Let me return to my own country.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why?” Pharaoh asked him. “What do you lack here that makes you want to go home?”
“Nothing,” he replied. “But even so, please let me return home.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God also raised up Rezon son of Eliada as Solomon’s adversary. Rezon had fled from his master, King Hadadezer of Zobah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and had become the leader of a gang of rebels. After David conquered Hadadezer, Rezon and his men fled to Damascus, where he became king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rezon was Israel’s bitter adversary for the rest of Solomon’s reign, and he made trouble, just as Hadad did. Rezon hated Israel intensely and continued to reign in Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Another rebel leader was Jeroboam son of Nebat, one of Solomon’s own officials. He came from the town of Zeredah in Ephraim, and his mother was Zeruah, a widow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the story behind his rebellion. Solomon was rebuilding the supporting terraces and repairing the walls of the city of his father, David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam was a very capable young man, and when Solomon saw how industrious he was, he put him in charge of the labor force from the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh, the descendants of Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day as Jeroboam was leaving Jerusalem, the prophet Ahijah from Shiloh met him along the way. Ahijah was wearing a new cloak. The two of them were alone in a field,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Ahijah took hold of the new cloak he was wearing and tore it into twelve pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to Jeroboam, “Take ten of these pieces, for this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: ‘I am about to tear the kingdom from the hand of Solomon, and I will give ten of the tribes to you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will leave him one tribe for the sake of my servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For Solomon has abandoned me and worshiped Ashtoreth, the goddess of the Sidonians; Chemosh, the god of Moab; and Molech, the god of the Ammonites. He has not followed my ways and done what is pleasing in my sight. He has not obeyed my decrees and regulations as David his father did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘But I will not take the entire kingdom from Solomon at this time. For the sake of my servant David, the one whom I chose and who obeyed my commands and decrees, I will keep Solomon as leader for the rest of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will take the kingdom away from his son and give ten of the tribes to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His son will have one tribe so that the descendants of David my servant will continue to reign, shining like a lamp in Jerusalem, the city I have chosen to be the place for my name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will place you on the throne of Israel, and you will rule over all that your heart desires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you listen to what I tell you and follow my ways and do whatever I consider to be right, and if you obey my decrees and commands, as my servant David did, then I will always be with you. I will establish an enduring dynasty for you as I did for David, and I will give Israel to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of Solomon’s sin I will punish the descendants of David—though not forever.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon tried to kill Jeroboam, but he fled to King Shishak of Egypt and stayed there until Solomon died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Solomon’s reign, including all his deeds and his wisdom, are recorded in The Book of the Acts of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon ruled in Jerusalem over all Israel for forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he died, he was buried in the City of David, named for his father. Then his son Rehoboam became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam went to Shechem, where all Israel had gathered to make him king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jeroboam son of Nebat heard of this, he returned from Egypt, for he had fled to Egypt to escape from King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The leaders of Israel summoned him, and Jeroboam and the whole assembly of Israel went to speak with Rehoboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your father was a hard master,” they said. “Lighten the harsh labor demands and heavy taxes that your father imposed on us. Then we will be your loyal subjects.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam replied, “Give me three days to think this over. Then come back for my answer.” So the people went away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Rehoboam discussed the matter with the older men who had counseled his father, Solomon. “What is your advice?” he asked. “How should I answer these people?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The older counselors replied, “If you are willing to be a servant to these people today and give them a favorable answer, they will always be your loyal subjects.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam rejected the advice of the older men and instead asked the opinion of the young men who had grown up with him and were now his advisers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What is your advice?” he asked them. “How should I answer these people who want me to lighten the burdens imposed by my father?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young men replied, “This is what you should tell those complainers who want a lighter burden: ‘My little finger is thicker than my father’s waist!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, my father laid heavy burdens on you, but I’m going to make them even heavier! My father beat you with whips, but I will beat you with scorpions!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later Jeroboam and all the people returned to hear Rehoboam’s decision, just as the king had ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam spoke harshly to the people, for he rejected the advice of the older counselors
verses.speaker: Narrator
