verses.text: and followed the counsel of his younger advisers. He told the people, “My father laid heavy burdens on you, but I’m going to make them even heavier! My father beat you with whips, but I will beat you with scorpions!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king paid no attention to the people. This turn of events was the will of the Lord, for it fulfilled the Lord’s message to Jeroboam son of Nebat through the prophet Ahijah from Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When all Israel realized that the king had refused to listen to them, they responded,
“Down with the dynasty of David!
    We have no interest in the son of Jesse.
Back to your homes, O Israel!
    Look out for your own house, O David!”
So the people of Israel returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam continued to rule over the Israelites who lived in the towns of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam sent Adoniram, who was in charge of forced labor, to restore order, but the people of Israel stoned him to death. When this news reached King Rehoboam, he quickly jumped into his chariot and fled to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And to this day the northern tribes of Israel have refused to be ruled by a descendant of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Israel learned of Jeroboam’s return from Egypt, they called an assembly and made him king over all Israel. So only the tribe of Judah remained loyal to the family of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam arrived at Jerusalem, he mobilized the men of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin—180,000 select troops—to fight against the men of Israel and to restore the kingdom to himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God said to Shemaiah, the man of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say to Rehoboam son of Solomon, king of Judah, and to all the people of Judah and Benjamin, and to the rest of the people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord says: Do not fight against your relatives, the Israelites. Go back home, for what has happened is my doing!’” So they obeyed the message of the Lord and went home, as the Lord had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam then built up the city of Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim, and it became his capital. Later he went and built up the town of Peniel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam thought to himself, “Unless I am careful, the kingdom will return to the dynasty of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When these people go to Jerusalem to offer sacrifices at the Temple of the Lord, they will again give their allegiance to King Rehoboam of Judah. They will kill me and make him their king instead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So on the advice of his counselors, the king made two gold calves. He said to the people, “It is too much trouble for you to worship in Jerusalem. Look, Israel, these are the gods who brought you out of Egypt!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He placed these calf idols in Bethel and in Dan—at either end of his kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But this became a great sin, for the people worshiped the idols, traveling as far north as Dan to worship the one there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam also erected buildings at the pagan shrines and ordained priests from the common people—those who were not from the priestly tribe of Levi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jeroboam instituted a religious festival in Bethel, held on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, in imitation of the annual Festival of Shelters in Judah. There at Bethel he himself offered sacrifices to the calves he had made, and he appointed priests for the pagan shrines he had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, a day that he himself had designated, Jeroboam offered sacrifices on the altar at Bethel. He instituted a religious festival for Israel, and he went up to the altar to burn incense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the Lord’s command, a man of God from Judah went to Bethel, arriving there just as Jeroboam was approaching the altar to burn incense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then at the Lord’s command, he shouted, “O altar, altar! This is what the Lord says: A child named Josiah will be born into the dynasty of David. On you he will sacrifice the priests from the pagan shrines who come here to burn incense, and human bones will be burned on you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same day the man of God gave a sign to prove his message. He said, “The Lord has promised to give this sign: This altar will split apart, and its ashes will be poured out on the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Jeroboam heard the man of God speaking against the altar at Bethel, he pointed at him and shouted, “Seize that man!” But instantly the king’s hand became paralyzed in that position, and he couldn’t pull it back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the same time a wide crack appeared in the altar, and the ashes poured out, just as the man of God had predicted in his message from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king cried out to the man of God, “Please ask the Lord your God to restore my hand again!” So the man of God prayed to the Lord, and the king’s hand was restored and he could move it again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to the man of God, “Come to the palace with me and have something to eat, and I will give you a gift.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the man of God said to the king, “Even if you gave me half of everything you own, I would not go with you. I would not eat or drink anything in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Lord gave me this command: ‘You must not eat or drink anything while you are there, and do not return to Judah by the same way you came.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he left Bethel and went home another way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As it happened, there was an old prophet living in Bethel, and his sons came home and told him what the man of God had done in Bethel that day. They also told their father what the man had said to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The old prophet asked them, “Which way did he go?” So they showed their father which road the man of God had taken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Quick, saddle the donkey,” the old man said. So they saddled the donkey for him, and he mounted it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he rode after the man of God and found him sitting under a great tree. The old prophet asked him, “Are you the man of God who came from Judah?”
“Yes, I am,” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to the man of God, “Come home with me and eat some food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No, I cannot,” he replied. “I am not allowed to eat or drink anything here in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Lord gave me this command: ‘You must not eat or drink anything while you are there, and do not return to Judah by the same way you came.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the old prophet answered, “I am a prophet, too, just as you are. And an angel gave me this command from the Lord: ‘Bring him home with you so he can have something to eat and drink.’” But the old man was lying to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went back together, and the man of God ate and drank at the prophet’s home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then while they were sitting at the table, a command from the Lord came to the old prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He cried out to the man of God from Judah, “This is what the Lord says: You have defied the word of the Lord and have disobeyed the command the Lord your God gave you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You came back to this place and ate and drank where he told you not to eat or drink. Because of this, your body will not be buried in the grave of your ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the man of God had finished eating and drinking, the old prophet saddled his own donkey for him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the man of God started off again. But as he was traveling along, a lion came out and killed him. His body lay there on the road, with the donkey and the lion standing beside it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People who passed by saw the body lying in the road and the lion standing beside it, and they went and reported it in Bethel, where the old prophet lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the prophet heard the report, he said, “It is the man of God who disobeyed the Lord’s command. The Lord has fulfilled his word by causing the lion to attack and kill him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the prophet said to his sons, “Saddle a donkey for me.” So they saddled a donkey,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he went out and found the body lying in the road. The donkey and lion were still standing there beside it, for the lion had not eaten the body nor attacked the donkey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the prophet laid the body of the man of God on the donkey and took it back to the town to mourn over him and bury him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He laid the body in his own grave, crying out in grief, “Oh, my brother!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward the prophet said to his sons, “When I die, bury me in the grave where the man of God is buried. Lay my bones beside his bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the message the Lord told him to proclaim against the altar in Bethel and against the pagan shrines in the towns of Samaria will certainly come true.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But even after this, Jeroboam did not turn from his evil ways. He continued to choose priests from the common people. He appointed anyone who wanted to become a priest for the pagan shrines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This became a great sin and resulted in the utter destruction of Jeroboam’s dynasty from the face of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Jeroboam’s son Abijah became very sick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam told his wife, “Disguise yourself so that no one will recognize you as my wife. Then go to the prophet Ahijah at Shiloh—the man who told me I would become king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take him a gift of ten loaves of bread, some cakes, and a jar of honey, and ask him what will happen to the boy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam’s wife went to Ahijah’s home at Shiloh. He was an old man now and could no longer see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord had told Ahijah, “Jeroboam’s wife will come here, pretending to be someone else. She will ask you about her son, for he is very sick. Give her the answer I give you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when Ahijah heard her footsteps at the door, he called out, “Come in, wife of Jeroboam! Why are you pretending to be someone else?” Then he told her, “I have bad news for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give your husband, Jeroboam, this message from the Lord, the God of Israel: ‘I promoted you from the ranks of the common people and made you ruler over my people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I ripped the kingdom away from the family of David and gave it to you. But you have not been like my servant David, who obeyed my commands and followed me with all his heart and always did whatever I wanted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have done more evil than all who lived before you. You have made other gods for yourself and have made me furious with your gold calves. And since you have turned your back on me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bring disaster on your dynasty and will destroy every one of your male descendants, slave and free alike, anywhere in Israel. I will burn up your royal dynasty as one burns up trash until it is all gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The members of Jeroboam’s family who die in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the field will be eaten by vultures. I, the Lord, have spoken.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahijah said to Jeroboam’s wife, “Go on home, and when you enter the city, the child will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel will mourn for him and bury him. He is the only member of your family who will have a proper burial, for this child is the only good thing that the Lord, the God of Israel, sees in the entire family of Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In addition, the Lord will raise up a king over Israel who will destroy the family of Jeroboam. This will happen today, even now!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord will shake Israel like a reed whipped about in a stream. He will uproot the people of Israel from this good land that he gave their ancestors and will scatter them beyond the Euphrates River, for they have angered the Lord with the Asherah poles they have set up for worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will abandon Israel because Jeroboam sinned and made Israel sin along with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam’s wife returned to Tirzah, and the child died just as she walked through the door of her home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all Israel buried him and mourned for him, as the Lord had promised through the prophet Ahijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Jeroboam’s reign, including all his wars and how he ruled, are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam reigned in Israel twenty-two years. When Jeroboam died, his son Nadab became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Rehoboam son of Solomon was king in Judah. He was forty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city the Lord had chosen from among all the tribes of Israel as the place to honor his name. Rehoboam’s mother was Naamah, an Ammonite woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During Rehoboam’s reign, the people of Judah did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, provoking his anger with their sin, for it was even worse than that of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For they also built for themselves pagan shrines and set up sacred pillars and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every green tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were even male and female shrine prostitutes throughout the land. The people imitated the detestable practices of the pagan nations the Lord had driven from the land ahead of the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fifth year of King Rehoboam’s reign, King Shishak of Egypt came up and attacked Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ransacked the treasuries of the Lord’s Temple and the royal palace; he stole everything, including all the gold shields Solomon had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam later replaced them with bronze shields as substitutes, and he entrusted them to the care of the commanders of the guard who protected the entrance to the royal palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the king went to the Temple of the Lord, the guards would also take the shields and then return them to the guardroom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Rehoboam’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was constant war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam died, he was buried among his ancestors in the City of David. His mother was Naamah, an Ammonite woman. Then his son Abijam became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijam began to rule over Judah in the eighteenth year of Jeroboam’s reign in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He reigned in Jerusalem three years. His mother was Maacah, the granddaughter of Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He committed the same sins as his father before him, and he was not faithful to the Lord his God, as his ancestor David had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But for David’s sake, the Lord his God allowed his descendants to continue ruling, shining like a lamp, and he gave Abijam a son to rule after him in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For David had done what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight and had obeyed the Lord’s commands throughout his life, except in the affair concerning Uriah the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war between Abijam and Jeroboam throughout Abijam’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Abijam’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Judah. There was constant war between Abijam and Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abijam died, he was buried in the City of David. Then his son Asa became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa began to rule over Judah in the twentieth year of Jeroboam’s reign in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He reigned in Jerusalem forty-one years. His grandmother was Maacah, the granddaughter of Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight, as his ancestor David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He banished the male and female shrine prostitutes from the land and got rid of all the idols his ancestors had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He even deposed his grandmother Maacah from her position as queen mother because she had made an obscene Asherah pole. He cut down her obscene pole and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although the pagan shrines were not removed, Asa’s heart remained completely faithful to the Lord throughout his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought into the Temple of the Lord the silver and gold and the various items that he and his father had dedicated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was constant war between King Asa of Judah and King Baasha of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Baasha of Israel invaded Judah and fortified Ramah in order to prevent anyone from entering or leaving King Asa’s territory in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa responded by removing all the silver and gold that was left in the treasuries of the Temple of the Lord and the royal palace. He sent it with some of his officials to Ben-hadad son of Tabrimmon, son of Hezion, the king of Aram, who was ruling in Damascus, along with this message:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Let there be a treaty between you and me like the one between your father and my father. See, I am sending you a gift of silver and gold. Break your treaty with King Baasha of Israel so that he will leave me alone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben-hadad agreed to King Asa’s request and sent the commanders of his army to attack the towns of Israel. They conquered the towns of Ijon, Dan, Abel-beth-maacah, and all Kinnereth, and all the land of Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Baasha of Israel heard what was happening, he abandoned his project of fortifying Ramah and withdrew to Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Asa sent an order throughout Judah, requiring that everyone, without exception, help to carry away the building stones and timbers that Baasha had been using to fortify Ramah. Asa used these materials to fortify the town of Geba in Benjamin and the town of Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Asa’s reign—the extent of his power, everything he did, and the names of the cities he built—are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Judah. In his old age his feet became diseased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Asa died, he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David.
Then Jehoshaphat, Asa’s son, became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nadab son of Jeroboam began to rule over Israel in the second year of King Asa’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Israel two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he did what was evil in the Lord’s sight and followed the example of his father, continuing the sins that Jeroboam had led Israel to commit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Baasha son of Ahijah, from the tribe of Issachar, plotted against Nadab and assassinated him while he and the Israelite army were laying siege to the Philistine town of Gibbethon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baasha killed Nadab in the third year of King Asa’s reign in Judah, and he became the next king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He immediately slaughtered all the descendants of King Jeroboam, so that not one of the royal family was left, just as the Lord had promised concerning Jeroboam by the prophet Ahijah from Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was done because Jeroboam had provoked the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel, by the sins he had committed and the sins he had led Israel to commit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Nadab’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was constant war between King Asa of Judah and King Baasha of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baasha son of Ahijah began to rule over all Israel in the third year of King Asa’s reign in Judah. Baasha reigned in Tirzah twenty-four years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he did what was evil in the Lord’s sight and followed the example of Jeroboam, continuing the sins that Jeroboam had led Israel to commit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord was delivered to King Baasha by the prophet Jehu son of Hanani:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I lifted you out of the dust to make you ruler of my people Israel, but you have followed the evil example of Jeroboam. You have provoked my anger by causing my people Israel to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now I will destroy you and your family, just as I destroyed the descendants of Jeroboam son of Nebat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The members of Baasha’s family who die in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the field will be eaten by vultures.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Baasha’s reign and the extent of his power are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Baasha died, he was buried in Tirzah. Then his son Elah became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The message from the Lord against Baasha and his family came through the prophet Jehu son of Hanani. It was delivered because Baasha had done what was evil in the Lord’s sight (just as the family of Jeroboam had done), and also because Baasha had destroyed the family of Jeroboam. The Lord’s anger was provoked by Baasha’s sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elah son of Baasha began to rule over Israel in the twenty-sixth year of King Asa’s reign in Judah. He reigned in the city of Tirzah for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zimri, who commanded half of the royal chariots, made plans to kill him. One day in Tirzah, Elah was getting drunk at the home of Arza, the supervisor of the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zimri walked in and struck him down and killed him. This happened in the twenty-seventh year of King Asa’s reign in Judah. Then Zimri became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zimri immediately killed the entire royal family of Baasha, leaving him not even a single male child. He even destroyed distant relatives and friends.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zimri destroyed the dynasty of Baasha as the Lord had promised through the prophet Jehu.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This happened because of all the sins Baasha and his son Elah had committed, and because of the sins they led Israel to commit. They provoked the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel, with their worthless idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Elah’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zimri began to rule over Israel in the twenty-seventh year of King Asa’s reign in Judah, but his reign in Tirzah lasted only seven days. The army of Israel was then attacking the Philistine town of Gibbethon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard that Zimri had committed treason and had assassinated the king, that very day they chose Omri, commander of the army, as the new king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Omri led the entire army of Israel up from Gibbethon to attack Tirzah, Israel’s capital.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Zimri saw that the city had been taken, he went into the citadel of the palace and burned it down over himself and died in the flames.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he, too, had done what was evil in the Lord’s sight. He followed the example of Jeroboam in all the sins he had committed and led Israel to commit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Zimri’s reign and his conspiracy are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now the people of Israel were split into two factions. Half the people tried to make Tibni son of Ginath their king, while the other half supported Omri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Omri’s supporters defeated the supporters of Tibni. So Tibni was killed, and Omri became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri began to rule over Israel in the thirty-first year of King Asa’s reign in Judah. He reigned twelve years in all, six of them in Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Omri bought the hill now known as Samaria from its owner, Shemer, for 150 pounds of silver. He built a city on it and called the city Samaria in honor of Shemer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Omri did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, even more than any of the kings before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed the example of Jeroboam son of Nebat in all the sins he had committed and led Israel to commit. The people provoked the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel, with their worthless idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Omri’s reign, the extent of his power, and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Omri died, he was buried in Samaria. Then his son Ahab became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab son of Omri began to rule over Israel in the thirty-eighth year of King Asa’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria twenty-two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ahab son of Omri did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, even more than any of the kings before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And as though it were not enough to follow the sinful example of Jeroboam, he married Jezebel, the daughter of King Ethbaal of the Sidonians, and he began to bow down in worship of Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: First Ahab built a temple and an altar for Baal in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he set up an Asherah pole. He did more to provoke the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel, than any of the other kings of Israel before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was during his reign that Hiel, a man from Bethel, rebuilt Jericho. When he laid its foundations, it cost him the life of his oldest son, Abiram. And when he completed it and set up its gates, it cost him the life of his youngest son, Segub. This all happened according to the message from the Lord concerning Jericho spoken by Joshua son of Nun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Elijah, who was from Tishbe in Gilead, told King Ahab, “As surely as the Lord, the God of Israel, lives—the God I serve—there will be no dew or rain during the next few years until I give the word!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Elijah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go to the east and hide by Kerith Brook, near where it enters the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Drink from the brook and eat what the ravens bring you, for I have commanded them to bring you food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Elijah did as the Lord told him and camped beside Kerith Brook, east of the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ravens brought him bread and meat each morning and evening, and he drank from the brook.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after a while the brook dried up, for there was no rainfall anywhere in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Elijah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and live in the village of Zarephath, near the city of Sidon. I have instructed a widow there to feed you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he went to Zarephath. As he arrived at the gates of the village, he saw a widow gathering sticks, and he asked her, “Would you please bring me a little water in a cup?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she was going to get it, he called to her, “Bring me a bite of bread, too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But she said, “I swear by the Lord your God that I don’t have a single piece of bread in the house. And I have only a handful of flour left in the jar and a little cooking oil in the bottom of the jug. I was just gathering a few sticks to cook this last meal, and then my son and I will die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Elijah said to her, “Don’t be afraid! Go ahead and do just what you’ve said, but make a little bread for me first. Then use what’s left to prepare a meal for yourself and your son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: There will always be flour and olive oil left in your containers until the time when the Lord sends rain and the crops grow again!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she did as Elijah said, and she and Elijah and her family continued to eat for many days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was always enough flour and olive oil left in the containers, just as the Lord had promised through Elijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later the woman’s son became sick. He grew worse and worse, and finally he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said to Elijah, “O man of God, what have you done to me? Have you come here to point out my sins and kill my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Elijah replied, “Give me your son.” And he took the child’s body from her arms, carried him up the stairs to the room where he was staying, and laid the body on his bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah cried out to the Lord, “O Lord my God, why have you brought tragedy to this widow who has opened her home to me, causing her son to die?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he stretched himself out over the child three times and cried out to the Lord, “O Lord my God, please let this child’s life return to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord heard Elijah’s prayer, and the life of the child returned, and he revived!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah brought him down from the upper room and gave him to his mother. “Look!” he said. “Your son is alive!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the woman told Elijah, “Now I know for sure that you are a man of God, and that the Lord truly speaks through you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later on, in the third year of the drought, the Lord said to Elijah, “Go and present yourself to King Ahab. Tell him that I will soon send rain!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Elijah went to appear before Ahab.
Meanwhile, the famine had become very severe in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab summoned Obadiah, who was in charge of the palace. (Obadiah was a devoted follower of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once when Jezebel had tried to kill all the Lord’s prophets, Obadiah had hidden 100 of them in two caves. He put fifty prophets in each cave and supplied them with food and water.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab said to Obadiah, “We must check every spring and valley in the land to see if we can find enough grass to save at least some of my horses and mules.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they divided the land between them. Ahab went one way by himself, and Obadiah went another way by himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Obadiah was walking along, he suddenly saw Elijah coming toward him. Obadiah recognized him at once and bowed low to the ground before him. “Is it really you, my lord Elijah?” he asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yes, it is,” Elijah replied. “Now go and tell your master, ‘Elijah is here.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Oh, sir,” Obadiah protested, “what harm have I done to you that you are sending me to my death at the hands of Ahab?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I swear by the Lord your God that the king has searched every nation and kingdom on earth from end to end to find you. And each time he was told, ‘Elijah isn’t here,’ King Ahab forced the king of that nation to swear to the truth of his claim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now you say, ‘Go and tell your master, “Elijah is here.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as soon as I leave you, the Spirit of the Lord will carry you away to who knows where. When Ahab comes and cannot find you, he will kill me. Yet I have been a true servant of the Lord all my life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Has no one told you, my lord, about the time when Jezebel was trying to kill the Lord’s prophets? I hid 100 of them in two caves and supplied them with food and water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now you say, ‘Go and tell your master, “Elijah is here.”’ Sir, if I do that, Ahab will certainly kill me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Elijah said, “I swear by the Lord Almighty, in whose presence I stand, that I will present myself to Ahab this very day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Obadiah went to tell Ahab that Elijah had come, and Ahab went out to meet Elijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahab saw him, he exclaimed, “So, is it really you, you troublemaker of Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I have made no trouble for Israel,” Elijah replied. “You and your family are the troublemakers, for you have refused to obey the commands of the Lord and have worshiped the images of Baal instead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now summon all Israel to join me at Mount Carmel, along with the 450 prophets of Baal and the 400 prophets of Asherah who are supported by Jezebel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab summoned all the people of Israel and the prophets to Mount Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah stood in front of them and said, “How much longer will you waver, hobbling between two opinions? If the Lord is God, follow him! But if Baal is God, then follow him!” But the people were completely silent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah said to them, “I am the only prophet of the Lord who is left, but Baal has 450 prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now bring two bulls. The prophets of Baal may choose whichever one they wish and cut it into pieces and lay it on the wood of their altar, but without setting fire to it. I will prepare the other bull and lay it on the wood on the altar, but not set fire to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then call on the name of your god, and I will call on the name of the Lord. The god who answers by setting fire to the wood is the true God!” And all the people agreed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah said to the prophets of Baal, “You go first, for there are many of you. Choose one of the bulls, and prepare it and call on the name of your god. But do not set fire to the wood.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they prepared one of the bulls and placed it on the altar. Then they called on the name of Baal from morning until noontime, shouting, “O Baal, answer us!” But there was no reply of any kind. Then they danced, hobbling around the altar they had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About noontime Elijah began mocking them. “You’ll have to shout louder,” he scoffed, “for surely he is a god! Perhaps he is daydreaming, or is relieving himself. Or maybe he is away on a trip, or is asleep and needs to be wakened!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they shouted louder, and following their normal custom, they cut themselves with knives and swords until the blood gushed out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They raved all afternoon until the time of the evening sacrifice, but still there was no sound, no reply, no response.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah called to the people, “Come over here!” They all crowded around him as he repaired the altar of the Lord that had been torn down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took twelve stones, one to represent each of the tribes of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he used the stones to rebuild the altar in the name of the Lord. Then he dug a trench around the altar large enough to hold about three gallons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He piled wood on the altar, cut the bull into pieces, and laid the pieces on the wood.
Then he said, “Fill four large jars with water, and pour the water over the offering and the wood.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had done this, he said, “Do the same thing again!” And when they were finished, he said, “Now do it a third time!” So they did as he said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the water ran around the altar and even filled the trench.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the usual time for offering the evening sacrifice, Elijah the prophet walked up to the altar and prayed, “O Lord, God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, prove today that you are God in Israel and that I am your servant. Prove that I have done all this at your command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O Lord, answer me! Answer me so these people will know that you, O Lord, are God and that you have brought them back to yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Immediately the fire of the Lord flashed down from heaven and burned up the young bull, the wood, the stones, and the dust. It even licked up all the water in the trench!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when all the people saw it, they fell face down on the ground and cried out, “The Lord—he is God! Yes, the Lord is God!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah commanded, “Seize all the prophets of Baal. Don’t let a single one escape!” So the people seized them all, and Elijah took them down to the Kishon Valley and killed them there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah said to Ahab, “Go get something to eat and drink, for I hear a mighty rainstorm coming!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab went to eat and drink. But Elijah climbed to the top of Mount Carmel and bowed low to the ground and prayed with his face between his knees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he said to his servant, “Go and look out toward the sea.”
The servant went and looked, then returned to Elijah and said, “I didn’t see anything.”
Seven times Elijah told him to go and look.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Finally the seventh time, his servant told him, “I saw a little cloud about the size of a man’s hand rising from the sea.”
Then Elijah shouted, “Hurry to Ahab and tell him, ‘Climb into your chariot and go back home. If you don’t hurry, the rain will stop you!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And soon the sky was black with clouds. A heavy wind brought a terrific rainstorm, and Ahab left quickly for Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord gave special strength to Elijah. He tucked his cloak into his belt and ran ahead of Ahab’s chariot all the way to the entrance of Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahab got home, he told Jezebel everything Elijah had done, including the way he had killed all the prophets of Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jezebel sent this message to Elijah: “May the gods strike me and even kill me if by this time tomorrow I have not killed you just as you killed them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah was afraid and fled for his life. He went to Beersheba, a town in Judah, and he left his servant there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went on alone into the wilderness, traveling all day. He sat down under a solitary broom tree and prayed that he might die. “I have had enough, Lord,” he said. “Take my life, for I am no better than my ancestors who have already died.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he lay down and slept under the broom tree. But as he was sleeping, an angel touched him and told him, “Get up and eat!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He looked around and there beside his head was some bread baked on hot stones and a jar of water! So he ate and drank and lay down again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of the Lord came again and touched him and said, “Get up and eat some more, or the journey ahead will be too much for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he got up and ate and drank, and the food gave him enough strength to travel forty days and forty nights to Mount Sinai, the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There he came to a cave, where he spent the night.
But the Lord said to him, “What are you doing here, Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah replied, “I have zealously served the Lord God Almighty. But the people of Israel have broken their covenant with you, torn down your altars, and killed every one of your prophets. I am the only one left, and now they are trying to kill me, too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go out and stand before me on the mountain,” the Lord told him. And as Elijah stood there, the Lord passed by, and a mighty windstorm hit the mountain. It was such a terrible blast that the rocks were torn loose, but the Lord was not in the wind. After the wind there was an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after the earthquake there was a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. And after the fire there was the sound of a gentle whisper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Elijah heard it, he wrapped his face in his cloak and went out and stood at the entrance of the cave.
And a voice said, “What are you doing here, Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied again, “I have zealously served the Lord God Almighty. But the people of Israel have broken their covenant with you, torn down your altars, and killed every one of your prophets. I am the only one left, and now they are trying to kill me, too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told him, “Go back the same way you came, and travel to the wilderness of Damascus. When you arrive there, anoint Hazael to be king of Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then anoint Jehu grandson of Nimshi to be king of Israel, and anoint Elisha son of Shaphat from the town of Abel-meholah to replace you as my prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who escapes from Hazael will be killed by Jehu, and those who escape Jehu will be killed by Elisha!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet I will preserve 7,000 others in Israel who have never bowed down to Baal or kissed him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Elijah went and found Elisha son of Shaphat plowing a field. There were twelve teams of oxen in the field, and Elisha was plowing with the twelfth team. Elijah went over to him and threw his cloak across his shoulders and then walked away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Elisha left the oxen standing there, ran after Elijah, and said to him, “First let me go and kiss my father and mother good-bye, and then I will go with you!”
Elijah replied, “Go on back, but think about what I have done to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Elisha returned to his oxen and slaughtered them. He used the wood from the plow to build a fire to roast their flesh. He passed around the meat to the townspeople, and they all ate. Then he went with Elijah as his assistant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About that time King Ben-hadad of Aram mobilized his army, supported by the chariots and horses of thirty-two allied kings. They went to besiege Samaria, the capital of Israel, and launched attacks against it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben-hadad sent messengers into the city to relay this message to King Ahab of Israel: “This is what Ben-hadad says:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Your silver and gold are mine, and so are your wives and the best of your children!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All right, my lord the king,” Israel’s king replied. “All that I have is yours!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Soon Ben-hadad’s messengers returned again and said, “This is what Ben-hadad says: ‘I have already demanded that you give me your silver, gold, wives, and children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But about this time tomorrow I will send my officials to search your palace and the homes of your officials. They will take away everything you consider valuable!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahab summoned all the elders of the land and said to them, “Look how this man is stirring up trouble! I already agreed with his demand that I give him my wives and children and silver and gold.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t give in to any more demands,” all the elders and the people advised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab told the messengers from Ben-hadad, “Say this to my lord the king: ‘I will give you everything you asked for the first time, but I cannot accept this last demand of yours.’” So the messengers returned to Ben-hadad with that response.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ben-hadad sent this message to Ahab: “May the gods strike me and even kill me if there remains enough dust from Samaria to provide even a handful for each of my soldiers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel sent back this answer: “A warrior putting on his sword for battle should not boast like a warrior who has already won.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab’s reply reached Ben-hadad and the other kings as they were drinking in their tents. “Prepare to attack!” Ben-hadad commanded his officers. So they prepared to attack the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a certain prophet came to see King Ahab of Israel and told him, “This is what the Lord says: Do you see all these enemy forces? Today I will hand them all over to you. Then you will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahab asked, “How will he do it?”
And the prophet replied, “This is what the Lord says: The troops of the provincial commanders will do it.”
“Should we attack first?” Ahab asked.
“Yes,” the prophet answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab mustered the troops of the 232 provincial commanders. Then he called out the rest of the army of Israel, some 7,000 men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About noontime, as Ben-hadad and the thirty-two allied kings were still in their tents drinking themselves into a stupor,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the troops of the provincial commanders marched out of the city as the first contingent.
As they approached, Ben-hadad’s scouts reported to him, “Some troops are coming from Samaria.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take them alive,” Ben-hadad commanded, “whether they have come for peace or for war.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ahab’s provincial commanders and the entire army had now come out to fight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each Israelite soldier killed his Aramean opponent, and suddenly the entire Aramean army panicked and fled. The Israelites chased them, but King Ben-hadad and a few of his charioteers escaped on horses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the king of Israel destroyed the other horses and chariots and slaughtered the Arameans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward the prophet said to King Ahab, “Get ready for another attack. Begin making plans now, for the king of Aram will come back next spring.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After their defeat, Ben-hadad’s officers said to him, “The Israelite gods are gods of the hills; that is why they won. But we can beat them easily on the plains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only this time replace the kings with field commanders!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Recruit another army like the one you lost. Give us the same number of horses, chariots, and men, and we will fight against them on the plains. There’s no doubt that we will beat them.” So King Ben-hadad did as they suggested.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following spring he called up the Aramean army and marched out against Israel, this time at Aphek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel then mustered its army, set up supply lines, and marched out for battle. But the Israelite army looked like two little flocks of goats in comparison to the vast Aramean forces that filled the countryside!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man of God went to the king of Israel and said, “This is what the Lord says: The Arameans have said, ‘The Lord is a god of the hills and not of the plains.’ So I will defeat this vast army for you. Then you will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two armies camped opposite each other for seven days, and on the seventh day the battle began. The Israelites killed 100,000 Aramean foot soldiers in one day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest fled into the town of Aphek, but the wall fell on them and killed another 27,000. Ben-hadad fled into the town and hid in a secret room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben-hadad’s officers said to him, “Sir, we have heard that the kings of Israel are merciful. So let’s humble ourselves by wearing burlap around our waists and putting ropes on our heads, and surrender to the king of Israel. Then perhaps he will let you live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they put on burlap and ropes, and they went to the king of Israel and begged, “Your servant Ben-hadad says, ‘Please let me live!’”
The king of Israel responded, “Is he still alive? He is my brother!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men took this as a good sign and quickly picked up on his words. “Yes,” they said, “your brother Ben-hadad!”
“Go and get him,” the king of Israel told them. And when Ben-hadad arrived, Ahab invited him up into his chariot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ben-hadad told him, “I will give back the towns my father took from your father, and you may establish places of trade in Damascus, as my father did in Samaria.”
Then Ahab said, “I will release you under these conditions.” So they made a new treaty, and Ben-hadad was set free.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the Lord instructed one of the group of prophets to say to another man, “Hit me!” But the man refused to hit the prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the prophet told him, “Because you have not obeyed the voice of the Lord, a lion will kill you as soon as you leave me.” And when he had gone, a lion did attack and kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the prophet turned to another man and said, “Hit me!” So he struck the prophet and wounded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet placed a bandage over his eyes to disguise himself and then waited beside the road for the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the king passed by, the prophet called out to him, “Sir, I was in the thick of battle, and suddenly a man brought me a prisoner. He said, ‘Guard this man; if for any reason he gets away, you will either die or pay a fine of seventy-five pounds of silver!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But while I was busy doing something else, the prisoner disappeared!”
“Well, it’s your own fault,” the king replied. “You have brought the judgment on yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the prophet quickly pulled the bandage from his eyes, and the king of Israel recognized him as one of the prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet said to him, “This is what the Lord says: Because you have spared the man I said must be destroyed, now you must die in his place, and your people will die instead of his people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Israel went home to Samaria angry and sullen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was a man named Naboth, from Jezreel, who owned a vineyard in Jezreel beside the palace of King Ahab of Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Ahab said to Naboth, “Since your vineyard is so convenient to my palace, I would like to buy it to use as a vegetable garden. I will give you a better vineyard in exchange, or if you prefer, I will pay you for it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Naboth replied, “The Lord forbid that I should give you the inheritance that was passed down by my ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab went home angry and sullen because of Naboth’s answer. The king went to bed with his face to the wall and refused to eat!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What’s the matter?” his wife Jezebel asked him. “What’s made you so upset that you’re not eating?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I asked Naboth to sell me his vineyard or trade it, but he refused!” Ahab told her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Are you the king of Israel or not?” Jezebel demanded. “Get up and eat something, and don’t worry about it. I’ll get you Naboth’s vineyard!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she wrote letters in Ahab’s name, sealed them with his seal, and sent them to the elders and other leaders of the town where Naboth lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In her letters she commanded: “Call the citizens together for a time of fasting, and give Naboth a place of honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And then seat two scoundrels across from him who will accuse him of cursing God and the king. Then take him out and stone him to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the elders and other town leaders followed the instructions Jezebel had written in the letters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They called for a fast and put Naboth at a prominent place before the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the two scoundrels came and sat down across from him. And they accused Naboth before all the people, saying, “He cursed God and the king.” So he was dragged outside the town and stoned to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The town leaders then sent word to Jezebel, “Naboth has been stoned to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jezebel heard the news, she said to Ahab, “You know the vineyard Naboth wouldn’t sell you? Well, you can have it now! He’s dead!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab immediately went down to the vineyard of Naboth to claim it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord said to Elijah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go down to meet King Ahab of Israel, who rules in Samaria. He will be at Naboth’s vineyard in Jezreel, claiming it for himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give him this message: ‘This is what the Lord says: Wasn’t it enough that you killed Naboth? Must you rob him, too? Because you have done this, dogs will lick your blood at the very place where they licked the blood of Naboth!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“So, my enemy, you have found me!” Ahab exclaimed to Elijah.
“Yes,” Elijah answered, “I have come because you have sold yourself to what is evil in the Lord’s sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now the Lord says, ‘I will bring disaster on you and consume you. I will destroy every one of your male descendants, slave and free alike, anywhere in Israel!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am going to destroy your family as I did the family of Jeroboam son of Nebat and the family of Baasha son of Ahijah, for you have made me very angry and have led Israel into sin.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And regarding Jezebel, the Lord says, ‘Dogs will eat Jezebel’s body at the plot of land in Jezreel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The members of Ahab’s family who die in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the field will be eaten by vultures.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (No one else so completely sold himself to what was evil in the Lord’s sight as Ahab did under the influence of his wife Jezebel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His worst outrage was worshiping idols just as the Amorites had done—the people whom the Lord had driven out from the land ahead of the Israelites.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Ahab heard this message, he tore his clothing, dressed in burlap, and fasted. He even slept in burlap and went about in deep mourning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then another message from the Lord came to Elijah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do you see how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Because he has done this, I will not do what I promised during his lifetime. It will happen to his sons; I will destroy his dynasty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For three years there was no war between Aram and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then during the third year, King Jehoshaphat of Judah went to visit King Ahab of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the visit, the king of Israel said to his officials, “Do you realize that the town of Ramoth-gilead belongs to us? And yet we’ve done nothing to recapture it from the king of Aram!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he turned to Jehoshaphat and asked, “Will you join me in battle to recover Ramoth-gilead?”
Jehoshaphat replied to the king of Israel, “Why, of course! You and I are as one. My troops are your troops, and my horses are your horses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoshaphat added, “But first let’s find out what the Lord says.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king of Israel summoned the prophets, about 400 of them, and asked them, “Should I go to war against Ramoth-gilead, or should I hold back?”
They all replied, “Yes, go right ahead! The Lord will give the king victory.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat asked, “Is there not also a prophet of the Lord here? We should ask him the same question.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Israel replied to Jehoshaphat, “There is one more man who could consult the Lord for us, but I hate him. He never prophesies anything but trouble for me! His name is Micaiah son of Imlah.”
Jehoshaphat replied, “That’s not the way a king should talk! Let’s hear what he has to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Israel called one of his officials and said, “Quick! Bring Micaiah son of Imlah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Ahab of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah, dressed in their royal robes, were sitting on thrones at the threshing floor near the gate of Samaria. All of Ahab’s prophets were prophesying there in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of them, Zedekiah son of Kenaanah, made some iron horns and proclaimed, “This is what the Lord says: With these horns you will gore the Arameans to death!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the other prophets agreed. “Yes,” they said, “go up to Ramoth-gilead and be victorious, for the Lord will give the king victory!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the messenger who went to get Micaiah said to him, “Look, all the prophets are promising victory for the king. Be sure that you agree with them and promise success.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Micaiah replied, “As surely as the Lord lives, I will say only what the Lord tells me to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Micaiah arrived before the king, Ahab asked him, “Micaiah, should we go to war against Ramoth-gilead, or should we hold back?”
Micaiah replied sarcastically, “Yes, go up and be victorious, for the Lord will give the king victory!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king replied sharply, “How many times must I demand that you speak only the truth to me when you speak for the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Micaiah told him, “In a vision I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains, like sheep without a shepherd. And the Lord said, ‘Their master has been killed. Send them home in peace.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Didn’t I tell you?” the king of Israel exclaimed to Jehoshaphat. “He never prophesies anything but trouble for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Micaiah continued, “Listen to what the Lord says! I saw the Lord sitting on his throne with all the armies of heaven around him, on his right and on his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And the Lord said, ‘Who can entice Ahab to go into battle against Ramoth-gilead so he can be killed?’
“There were many suggestions,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and finally a spirit approached the Lord and said, ‘I can do it!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“‘How will you do this?’ the Lord asked.
“And the spirit replied, ‘I will go out and inspire all of Ahab’s prophets to speak lies.’
“‘You will succeed,’ said the Lord. ‘Go ahead and do it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So you see, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouths of all your prophets. For the Lord has pronounced your doom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zedekiah son of Kenaanah walked up to Micaiah and slapped him across the face. “Since when did the Spirit of the Lord leave me to speak to you?” he demanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Micaiah replied, “You will find out soon enough when you are trying to hide in some secret room!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Arrest him!” the king of Israel ordered. “Take him back to Amon, the governor of the city, and to my son Joash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give them this order from the king: ‘Put this man in prison, and feed him nothing but bread and water until I return safely from the battle!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Micaiah replied, “If you return safely, it will mean that the Lord has not spoken through me!” Then he added to those standing around, “Everyone mark my words!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Ahab of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah led their armies against Ramoth-gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “As we go into battle, I will disguise myself so no one will recognize me, but you wear your royal robes.” So the king of Israel disguised himself, and they went into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the king of Aram had issued these orders to his thirty-two chariot commanders: “Attack only the king of Israel. Don’t bother with anyone else!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when the Aramean chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat in his royal robes, they went after him. “There is the king of Israel!” they shouted. But when Jehoshaphat called out,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the chariot commanders realized he was not the king of Israel, and they stopped chasing him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: An Aramean soldier, however, randomly shot an arrow at the Israelite troops and hit the king of Israel between the joints of his armor. “Turn the horses and get me out of here!” Ahab groaned to the driver of his chariot. “I’m badly wounded!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle raged all that day, and the king remained propped up in his chariot facing the Arameans. The blood from his wound ran down to the floor of his chariot, and as evening arrived he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as the sun was setting, the cry ran through his troops: “We’re done for! Run for your lives!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king died, and his body was taken to Samaria and buried there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his chariot was washed beside the pool of Samaria, and dogs came and licked his blood at the place where the prostitutes bathed, just as the Lord had promised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Ahab’s reign and everything he did, including the story of the ivory palace and the towns he built, are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab died, and his son Ahaziah became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat son of Asa began to rule over Judah in the fourth year of King Ahab’s reign in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem twenty-five years. His mother was Azubah, the daughter of Shilhi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was a good king, following the example of his father, Asa. He did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight. During his reign, however, he failed to remove all the pagan shrines, and the people still offered sacrifices and burned incense there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat also made peace with the king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Jehoshaphat’s reign, the extent of his power, and the wars he waged are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He banished from the land the rest of the male and female shrine prostitutes, who still continued their practices from the days of his father, Asa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (There was no king in Edom at that time, only a deputy.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat also built a fleet of trading ships to sail to Ophir for gold. But the ships never set sail, for they met with disaster in their home port of Ezion-geber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At one time Ahaziah son of Ahab had proposed to Jehoshaphat, “Let my men sail with your men in the ships.” But Jehoshaphat refused the request.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jehoshaphat died, he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. Then his son Jehoram became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah son of Ahab began to rule over Israel in the seventeenth year of King Jehoshaphat’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, following the example of his father and mother and the example of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who had led Israel to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He served Baal and worshiped him, provoking the anger of the Lord, the God of Israel, just as his father had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator
